name: Arup Engineering Deepfake Video Conference Attack
summary: Sophisticated business email compromise (BEC) attack using AI-generated deepfake video to impersonate the CFO and other senior executives of Arup, a multinational engineering firm. Attackers conducted a fake video conference call where all participants except the victim were AI-generated deepfakes, convincing a finance employee to transfer HK$200 million (~$25.6M USD) across 15 transactions.

ai_technologies_used.description: Real-time AI-generated video impersonating multiple executives simultaneously
AI-synthesized voices matching known executives from public recordings
Live deepfake generation during video conference, not pre-recorded

attack_phases.name: Target Reconnaissance
attack_phases.description: Attackers researched target organization, identifying finance department employees and gathering publicly available video/audio of executives for deepfake training.
indicators: Executive video content scraped from YouTube/LinkedIn

attack_phases.name: Deepfake Model Training
attack_phases.description: AI models trained on publicly available video footage of CFO and other executives to generate convincing real-time deepfakes.

attack_phases.name: Phishing Lure
attack_phases.description: Employee received message (likely via email or messaging platform) requesting attendance at an urgent video conference with CFO regarding confidential transactions.

attack_phases.name: Deepfake Video Conference
attack_phases.description: Victim joined video call where multiple attendees appeared to be senior executives. All participants except the victim were AI-generated deepfakes. The fake CFO instructed the employee to make fund transfers.

social_engineering_details.pretext: Confidential business transaction requiring immediate transfers
social_engineering_details.success_factor: Multiple convincing deepfakes created appearance of legitimate executive meeting

attack_phases.name: Financial Theft
attack_phases.description: Employee executed 15 separate transfers totaling HK$200 million to accounts controlled by attackers before fraud was discovered.

pre_attack: Track unusual meeting invitations for sensitive topics
Alert on requests involving financial transactions via video
during_attack: Callback verification using known phone numbers
Code word/passphrase systems for sensitive requests
AI deepfake detection tools for video calls

mitre_attack_mapping.description: Meeting invitation to join fraudulent video conference
AI-generated voice used during video call
AI deepfake impersonation of multiple executives

lessons_learned: AI deepfakes can now impersonate multiple people in real-time video calls
Single-person authorization is insufficient for large transactions
Callback verification must use pre-established contact methods
Consider AI-powered deepfake detection for sensitive communications
Establish code words or passphrases for high-value requests
Video presence alone no longer confirms identity

defensive_recommendations.description: Require multiple independent approvals for transfers over threshold
Verify requests via separate communication channel (phone callback to known number)
Deploy AI-powered tools to detect synthetic video/audio in calls
Train employees on deepfake risks and verification procedures
